meta.title: kPa to PSI Converter – Kilopascals to Pounds per Square Inch
meta.description: Convert kilopascals (kPa) to pounds per square inch (psi) and back with a precise, NIST-traceable pressure converter. Includes quick table, lab and recipe use cases, calibration tips, and safety notes for compressed gases and tire pressure.

hero.title: Convert kPa to PSI
hero.h1: kPa to PSI – Kilopascal to Pound per Square Inch Converter
hero.tagline: Engineering-grade kPa ⇄ psi conversions with practical safety and calibration guidance.

fields.name: psi
fields.label: Pressure in pounds per square inch
fields.aria_label: Pressure in pounds per square inch

data_notes: Conversion factor is based on NIST guidance: 1 kPa = 0.1450377377 psi (exact within rounding).

examples.label: Standard atmospheric pressure at sea level
examples.description: Approximate standard atmosphere used in many engineering references, including Penn State Mechanical Engineering and MIT OpenCourseWare fluid mechanics notes.

examples.label: Typical car tire pressure
examples.description: Many passenger car tires are in the range 200–300 kPa (30–44 psi). Always follow the vehicle manufacturer's placard.

examples.label: Autoclave / pressure cooker sterilization band
examples.description: Lab and kitchen sterilization cycles often operate around 100–200 kPa above atmospheric (roughly 15–30 psi gauge). Check your equipment manual for exact limits.

examples.label: Compressed gas cylinder threshold
examples.description: OSHA and university EHS guidance often treat gases above about 40 psi (≈ 276 kPa) as compressed gas and subject to specific handling requirements.

conversion_table.title: Quick kPa to psi conversion table
conversion_table.caption: Engineering-friendly kPa ⇄ psi values rounded to 4 decimal places. For design or safety compliance, use manufacturer data and relevant standards.

body.lead: Use this kPa to psi converter when you need a dependable, engineering-grade pressure conversion for lab work, calibration sheets, process design, or even recipes that specify pressure in kilopascals or pounds per square inch.

sections.title: How to use the kPa to psi converter
body: 1. Enter your known pressure value in either the kilopascal (kPa) or psi field.
2. The other field updates instantly using a high-precision NIST-traceable conversion factor (1 kPa = 0.1450377377 psi).
3. Use the quick table below for common setpoints (tire pressure, autoclaves, compressed gases, and lab equipment).
4. For critical operations (e.g., oxygen cylinders, high-pressure reactors, pressure vessels) always compare your results with manufacturer documentation and applicable standards.

sections.title: kPa to psi formula and definition of units
body: Pressure is defined as force per unit area. In SI units, the pascal (Pa) is one newton per square metre (N/m²). A kilopascal (kPa) is 1000 Pa and is widely used in engineering, fluid mechanics, and meteorology.

In the inch-pound system, pounds per square inch (psi) is defined as one pound-force acting uniformly on an area of one square inch. It remains common in tire pressure ratings, compressed gas cylinders, and legacy equipment specifications.
The exact relationship used here follows NIST conversion guidance:

These factors are consistent with NIST publications on SI units and conversion factors, such as the NIST Guide to the SI and NIST Handbook 44 Appendix C, as well as university fluid mechanics references (e.g. Penn State Mechanical Engineering and MIT OpenCourseWare).

sections.title: Calibration, safety margins, and instrument limits
body: For safety-critical applications, the conversion factor is only one piece of the puzzle. You must also respect instrument ranges, calibration dates, and applicable regulations:

• Compressed gases: OSHA 29 CFR 1910.101 and related guidance from university Environmental Health & Safety offices define how compressed gas cylinders are classified, stored, and inspected. Many of these documents still reference psi, while modern specifications for regulators, piping, and relief devices are often given in kPa.

• Cylinders and regulators: Typical cylinders and regulators carry maximum working pressures expressed in both kPa (or bar) and psi. Our converter helps you interpret labels and datasheets, but you must never exceed the lowest rated value across the system.

• Laboratory equipment: Autoclaves, reactors, and pressure vessels specify allowed operating ranges, often in kPa or bar with psi equivalents in the manual. Always treat any converted value as an approximation and follow the manufacturer limits as the source of truth.

• Calibration: For QA/QC in labs and plants, pressure gauges and transmitters are often calibrated against NIST-traceable standards. Where possible, use calibration certificates and documentation from accredited labs rather than hand-typed conversions.

For high-consequence scenarios (compressed oxygen, acetylene, high-pressure steam, or process gases), treat this converter as a design and documentation aid, not as a substitute for formal engineering calculations or safety reviews.

sections.title: Recipes, lab protocols, and practical examples
body: You will increasingly see pressures written in kilopascals in both lab protocols and high-end cooking references:

• Pressure cookers and autoclaves: Many sterilization cycles target roughly 15–30 psi over atmospheric pressure, corresponding to about 100–200 kPa gauge. This converter lets you translate between recipe instructions (often written in psi) and equipment manuals (often in kPa or bar).

• Espresso and beverage systems: Pump pressures may be specified in bar or kPa; some service documents reference psi. Using a consistent kPa ⇄ psi converter helps with maintenance logs and troubleshooting.

• Lab experiments and teaching: University notes on fluid mechanics frequently give examples in both kPa and psi when discussing hydrostatics, manometers, and pump curves. If you are preparing lab sheets or grading, using a consistent conversion factor avoids rounding drift across examples.

For food safety, always follow time-temperature-pressure combinations given by reputable sources. For laboratory work, align your setpoints with validated protocols and your institution's safety office.

sections.title: Limitations and responsible use
body: This tool is designed for accurate numerical conversion between kPa and psi, not for approving any operating condition as safe. Do not treat a converted value as a certification that a given pressure is acceptable.
For compliance with codes and standards (pressure vessels, boilers, gas cylinders, medical gases), always defer to:
• Manufacturer nameplate and documentation
• Engineering calculations and design reports
• Applicable standards and regulations (e.g., ASME codes, OSHA rules, national metrology guidance)
Use this converter to reduce transcription errors, harmonize units across documents, and add clarity to your technical communication.

faq.question: What is a kilopascal (kPa) in simple terms?
faq.answer: A kilopascal (kPa) is a metric unit of pressure equal to 1000 pascals (Pa). One pascal is one newton of force acting on one square metre of area. Kilopascals are widely used for tire pressure, hydraulics, HVAC systems, and lab instruments because they fit typical engineering ranges better than single pascals. NIST and international metrology institutes treat the pascal as the coherent SI unit of pressure, with kPa as a convenient multiple.

faq.question: What is pounds per square inch (psi)?
faq.answer: Pounds per square inch (psi) is a non-SI unit of pressure used primarily in the United States and in older equipment specifications. It represents one pound-force distributed over one square inch of area. You still see psi for tire pressure, compressed gas cylinders, hydraulic systems, and legacy process equipment. Many universities and engineering courses present both kPa and psi in worked examples to help students bridge between SI and inch-pound systems.

faq.question: What is the exact formula to convert kPa to psi?
faq.answer: The converter uses the NIST-consistent relationship between SI and inch-pound units. The formula is: psi = kPa × 0.1450377377. The inverse formula is kPa = psi × 6.894757293. These factors are aligned with NIST conversion tables and are widely used in engineering textbooks and university lecture notes.

faq.question: Does this calculator use gauge pressure or absolute pressure?
faq.answer: The conversion between kPa and psi is the same for gauge and absolute pressures: only the reference point changes. If your instrument or datasheet says kPa(g) and psi(g), you can convert numerically between them with the same factors. What you must not do is mix a gauge value with an absolute value without adjusting for atmospheric pressure (roughly 100–101 kPa or about 14.7 psi at sea level). For safety and design, always read whether the document is using gauge, absolute, or differential pressure.

faq.question: Can I use this to decide whether a pressure is safe for my cylinder or vessel?
faq.answer: No. This calculator only performs unit conversion. Whether a given pressure is safe depends on the design code, material, temperature, corrosion allowance, and safety factors of your system. For compressed gas cylinders and pressure vessels, rely on the manufacturer nameplate, certified design documents, and standards such as ASME codes and OSHA requirements. Use this tool to translate units when reading those documents, not to override them.

faq.question: Is this kPa to psi converter suitable for recipes and autoclave cycles?
faq.answer: Yes, as long as you use it as a numeric aid and still follow validated time–temperature–pressure combinations. Some high-end cooking and microbiology texts specify pressure in kPa above atmospheric, while equipment manuals may use psi or bar. Converting consistently between kPa and psi reduces mistakes when you are configuring a pressure cooker, autoclave, or other sealed vessel. Always stay within the device's rated pressure range and follow food safety or biosafety guidance from trusted authorities or your institution.

faq.question: How should I document kPa and psi when calibrating gauges and sensors?
faq.answer: Best practice in labs and industrial plants is to record both the nominal pressure and the unit, and where possible, reference a NIST-traceable standard or accredited calibration lab. Many calibration certificates list points in kPa, bar, and psi. Using a single, well-documented conversion factor (such as the one used in this calculator) helps keep your calibration sheets consistent with standards from NIST, national metrology institutes, and university reference materials.

mainEntity.name: What is a kilopascal (kPa) in simple terms?

acceptedAnswer.text: A kilopascal (kPa) is a metric unit of pressure equal to 1000 pascals (Pa). One pascal is one newton of force acting on one square metre of area. Kilopascals are widely used for tire pressure, hydraulics, HVAC systems, and lab instruments.

mainEntity.name: What is pounds per square inch (psi)?

acceptedAnswer.text: Pounds per square inch (psi) is a non-SI unit of pressure representing one pound-force acting on an area of one square inch. It is common in tire pressure, compressed gas cylinders, hydraulic systems, and legacy equipment.

mainEntity.name: What is the exact formula to convert kPa to psi?

acceptedAnswer.text: The formula is psi = kPa × 0.1450377377. The inverse is kPa = psi × 6.894757293. These factors are aligned with NIST conversion tables and widely used in engineering references.

mainEntity.name: Does this calculator use gauge pressure or absolute pressure?

acceptedAnswer.text: The numerical conversion between kPa and psi is the same for gauge and absolute pressure. The difference lies in the reference point (atmospheric vs absolute zero). Always check whether your datasheet uses gauge, absolute, or differential pressure.

mainEntity.name: Can I use this to decide whether a pressure is safe for my cylinder or vessel?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. This tool only converts units. Safety depends on design codes, materials, and regulations. Always follow manufacturer limits and applicable standards such as ASME and OSHA requirements.
